instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

We have an Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that did not turn on. USB-C meter showed stuck at 5V could not switch to 20V. We opened the back cover and we saw very dusty PCB. Removed PCB and checked under the microscope for possible corrosion. parts near to power chips / USB-C - 4 of them, were dusty. We cleaned them and then used thermal camera to analyze the board to see if we can detect any shorted element on it. We found one shorted capacitor which got hot (<CAPACITOR>C9588</CAPACITOR>). Also we saw that <CHIP>U5620</CHIP> has corrosions on legs(<SIGNAL>ISNS_PPBUS_MAIN_SSD0_P</SIGNAL>). We removed it, cleaned the area and put a working donor <CHIP>U5620</CHIP> chip from the working PCB. We also removed <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> to check the legs but everything was ok on this chip mechanically. 

We powered the mainboard without connecting it to battery. The volt switched from 5V to 20V and stayed at 0.05amps. We put the board back to computer and the computer started to use amps, we believe it was charging and amps went to from 0.05 to 2.5-2.7. After charging finished, we came back the next day we see it 5V and is not charging. Pressing power button and voltage goes to  20v and charging starts. We do not hear any chip and we do not feel any warmness on CPU side. While checking L chips around the CPU such as L7420, L7211 we do not have voltage. Upon checking for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, we do not see any power/votlage as well. 

I need your help in this situation to move forward and to troubleshoot the issue. Please advise what to check. Thank you. See attachments as well.

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground readings at L9080/580.
Any SSD voltage appears?
Also check the G3S voltages.

Is the machine recognized in DFU?
You can try revive; go for restore, if no data needed.

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
Diode mode testing results:
L9080-GND - 0.43V
L9580-GND - 0.411V

SSD0
<CHIP>U9100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U9400</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 1.8v exist
<CHIP>U9100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U9400</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 2.5v exist
<CHIP>U9100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U9400</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 0.9v exist

SSD1
<CHIP>U8600</CHIP> --> <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 1.8v exist
<CHIP>U8600</CHIP> --> <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 2.5v exist
<CHIP>U8600</CHIP> --> <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> -> 0.9v exist

Some power lines. Let me know if any other power line need, I can check it. Not quiet experienced.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL> - missing power
<SIGNAL>5VG3S_VFB1_RR</SIGNAL> - 5v exist
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - missing power
<SIGNAL>P1V8G3S_EN</SIGNAL> - 1.8v exist
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> - 1.8v exist
<SIGNAL>I2C_SNS_G3S_SCL</SIGNAL> - 1.8v exist
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> --> 12.5V exist
<SIGNAL>P5V_3V3G3H_EN</SIGNAL> -> 3.3v exist
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> - 1.8v exist

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
The readings look good.

"Is the machine recognized in DFU?
You can try revive; go for restore, if no data needed."

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
Thank you. I connected the board directly to Mac Mini over charger cable and opened Apple Configurator 2, it did not detect it in DFU mode. No activity on Apple Configurator 2 at all. 

I have a few questions. 
When connected to charging cable, i do not feel any warmness on GPU and CPU. Also checked elements around GPU and CPU, power is missing such as: Is this normal? 

PCVDDCIMEM_GPU_R - missing power
<SIGNAL>PP0V85_MEMCI_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> - missing power

Mainboard standalone means without connecting it to MacBook itself, should it be detect in DFU mode in Apple Configurator 2? Should we do something to make it go to DFU mode?

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL]

Be aware, this board requires 96/140W charger to boot!

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
according my experience, if the board is in DFU mode, when you connect it to another Mac with apple configuration2 , it detects and shows it on the screen. Also the GPU and CPU area should be getting warm I think. Can you confirm this?

But when we connect, it does not detect it in DFU mode. Should we force to DFU mode? Thank you.

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message:
This machine REQUIRES 96, or 140W charger!

DFU mode doesn't need CPU to run.
Force it in DFU, if no other way.

threads.title: Apple MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> / Short on PCB
threads.message: We got DFU mode, revived the MacBook and got access to the data. Thank you for your help.
